entry.title: SAP UX Q1/2026 Update ‚Äì Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start
entry.content:
This series of posts gives an overview of user experience innovations in the cloud from the last six months, covering our whole portfolio, such as AI and Joule, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602, SAP SuccessFactors etc., as well as covering  innovations in our UI technologies for building great UX.

In this first post, we‚Äôll look at the latest cross-suite UX innovations, coming from Joule, SAP Work Zone and SAP Mobile Start. Highlights are the general availability of Joule Agent Builder as well as Document AI for SAP Mobile Start, and the two brand new innovations in beta and early adopter care respectively: Joule Deep Research and Joule Action Bar, taking user experience to the next level.

Before we get started: if you haven‚Äôt already seen them, do have a look at the overview of public cloud UX innovations I posted in Q3/2025 (parts 2 to 7 are linked in part 1):

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

This upcoming series of posts includes Joule and AI UX highlights from individual products within the SAP Business Suite, but for a more comprehensive overview of our recent AI innovations, not just UX related, have a look at:

  • SAP Business AI: Release Highlights Q3 2025.
  • SAP Business AI: Release Highlights Q4/2025.
  • SAP Innovation Guide H2/2025 ‚Äì SAP Business AI.

 

Joule User Experience Innovations

Joule is the AI-powered copilot for SAP systems, offering a powerful new user experience, using natural language to access our cloud products and providing a seamless flow for the user wherever they are, on desktop, laptop or mobile devices.

First, we‚Äôll have a look at the latest generic or cross-product UX innovations, before I give you some pointers to the product-specific innovations as well as news about developing custom capabilities with the generally available Agent Builder.

This section covers these user experience innovations:

  • Joule Small Talk Pattern ‚Äì beyond just small talk.
  • Use Joule now in 13 languages (2 more added).
  • Joule, Deep research capability (Beta).
  • Joule Action Bar (EAC).
  • Joule on Mobile Devices ‚Äì now for SAP Sales Cloud too.
  • Joule Analytics Center For Analysing Usage.
  • Joule for Consultants: UX enhancement (Prompt Guide and Library).
  • Product-specific capabilities.
  • Customer-specific Agents: Agent Builder Available Now.

Joule Small Talk Pattern ‚Äì Beyond just Small Talk

Initially, you could say hello to Joule, and Joule would reply in a friendly way ‚Äì in other words, Joule could do small talk. In the mean time, we have significantly expanded the degree to which Joule supports general conversations.

Figure 1 shows an example, where the user has asked Joule the following:

I‚Äôm an HR manager preparing a script for a new hire onboarding presentation. The focus is on our company‚Äôs commitment to employee development, mentorship, and overall well-being. Please help me draft clear and engaging talking points that highlight why mentorship and professional growth are core values in our organization. Use the mission statement ‚Äúhelp the world to run better.

To which Joule responds with a structured answer, with sections containing bullet points with suggestions.


Figure 1: An example of Joule small talk pattern, going beyond just small talk, shown with Joule in full-screen mode. Alt Text: Screenshot of Joule with the example query shown at the top, and below that Joule‚Äôs answer with sections ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù, ‚ÄúCommitment to Employee Development‚Äù and ‚ÄúMentorship as a Core Value‚Äù visible.

Figure 2 gives an overview of all the five interaction patterns supported by Joule today ‚Äì the four patterns which interact with an SAP system, plus the small talk pattern.


Figure 2: The five Joule interaction patterns. Alt Text: Five images of Joule showing from left to right the Informational pattern (‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù), Navigational (‚ÄúWhere?‚Äù), Transactional (‚ÄúDo‚Äù), Analytical (‚ÄúShow me‚Äù) and Small Talk (‚ÄúBe creative‚Äù).

Use Joule in 13 Languages ‚Äì Two More Added

Since my last update, we have added support for Arabic and Indonesian, bringing the total up to 13. Here they are in alphabetical order, with the variant of the language in brackets.

  • Arabic
  • Chinese (Simplified)
  • English (US)
  • French (France)
  • German (Germany)
  • Greek
  • Indonesian
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • Polish
  • Portuguese (Brazil)
  • Spanish (Spain)
  • Vietnamese

In addition to these, we have four more languages available as a preview that are not yet officially supported:

  • Czech
  • Dutch (Netherlands)
  • Italian
  • Turkish

To get the most up-to-date information about language support for Joule, look at the documentation:

  • Joule Multi Language Support.

Joule, Deep Research Capability (Beta)

Currently available for beta-testing, the deep research capability means that Joule can provide much deeper insights in response to queries, by using external web resources in addition to those from your organization and SAP data.

One of our AI UX principles is ‚Äúhuman in control‚Äù, and hence we let users choose when they want a deep research analysis instead of the standard analysis (Figure X). Similarly, the deep research is done in two stages, where first the system shows the user the steps it plans to take in order to do the research, and asks the user to confirm before continuing (as shown in Figure Y).

Figures 3 ‚Äì 7 give you an idea of what it currently looks like, starting with the user selecting the deep research option, as shown in Figure 2. Joule then displays the research approval request, summarizing the steps it plans to take (Figure 4). Once the user has approved this, the research is done and the outcome shown. Finally, the user can expand the Sources section to get links to articles on which the research was based. In this case, the sources were all external.


Figure 3: Users can choose the answer type ‚ÄúDeep Research‚Äù (currently Beta) and then enter their question. Alt Text: Two images showing the text entry field for Joule, the upper one showing the context menu with the options for Answer Types ‚ÄúDefault‚Äù and ‚ÄúDeep Research‚Äù, the lower one showing a ‚ÄúDeep Research‚Äù token displayed in the field, with a query entered ‚ÄúWhat is the name and weight of the eBike MZ-FG-E164, compare it to the average weight of similar bikes found online for the top 3 market sellers in only Germany region in the past 6 months‚Äù.


Figure 4: Joule deep research (beta) provides research approval request to the user. Alt Text: Image showing the Joule providing a formatted text with ‚ÄúResearch Approval Request‚Äù in large bold font as the title, with sections ‚ÄúResearch Plan‚Äù and ‚ÄúScope‚Äù, each with bullet points outlining what Joule plans to do, such as ‚ÄúLook up the eBike model in internal systems‚Ä¶‚Äù, ‚ÄúResearch online sources..‚Äù.


Figure 5: The outcome of the deep research ‚Äì first page. Alt Text: Image showing that the user prompted ‚ÄúStart Deep Research‚Äù, followed by the beginning of the outcome text: the title in bold (‚ÄúComparison of ‚Ä¶ to Top German eBike Sellers‚Äô Models‚Äù), with sections ‚ÄúOverview‚Äù and ‚ÄúKey Findings‚Äù.


Figure 6: The outcome of the deep research ‚Äì second page. Alt Text: Image showing the section ‚ÄúAnalysis‚Äù with sub-sections ‚ÄúWeight Comparison by Category‚Äù and ‚ÄúComparative Analysis‚Äù, followed by the beginning of the section ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù.


Figure 7: The outcome of the deep research, with links to sources. Alt Text: Image showing the remainder of the Conclusion, with a sub-section ‚ÄúData Access Notice‚Äù, followed by a list of five sources with their titles and links to each of them.

To get an even better idea of how it works, watch it in action, or read more:

  • Video: Joule Deep Research example (2:06 minutes)
  • SAP Discovery Center: Joule, Deep research capability

Joule Action Bar (EAC)

The Joule Action Bar is an intelligent overlay in the browser that delivers AI on any application ‚Äì SAP and beyond.

It is available to early adopters as part of our early adopter care (EAC) program, allowing us to gather feedback from participating customers and iterate further before releasing it to everyone.

The Joule Action Bar hovers over your browser content and understands what users are currently doing. Powered by WalkMe‚Äôs unique technology that interprets screen-based content, it can proactively step in to provide guidance, as well as being called up by the user on-demand. A particularly powerful feature is personalization: users can personalize the experience by creating custom AI actions for everyday tasks, not only for SAP systems, also for others.

Figures 8 and 9 show an example where the action bar is being used to deal with a support ticket in ServiceNow that indicates that urgent action is required. Normally, the user would have to switch to a separate SAP screen and analyze the issue, but the Joule Action Bar provides a summary of the pertinant information such at your fingertips ‚Äì in this case the impact summary.


Figure 8: Joule action bar visible while processing a ticket in ServiceNow. Alt Text: A screenshot with the Joule action bar visible at the bottom of the screen, on top of a greyed-out ServiceNow ticket screen. The action bar offers icons to open Joule, and buttons ‚ÄúSuggestions‚Äù, ‚ÄúView supply chaing impact‚Äù, ‚ÄúTools‚Äù and personalization.


Figure 9: Joule action bar providing a summary of the supply chain impact. Alt Text: Image showing a pop-over ‚ÄúView supply chain impact‚Äù above the Joule action bar, summarizing the impact, explaining stock availability and providing a risk alert.

It‚Äôs main benefits are:

  • Always available in a user‚Äôs flow of work.
  • Detecting user needs in real time and offering help without being asked.
  • Proactively recommends next best actions based on screen-based and business context.
  • One consistent, unified and intuitive AI experience across SAP and non-SAP applications.
  • Personalization: allows users to create custom AI actions for their typical activities.

To get an even better idea of how it works, watch this short video:

  • Video: Joule Action Bar (1:15 minutes)
  • SAP Discovery Center: WalkMe, SAP Joule action bar (Proactive).
  • SAP Discovery Center: WalkMe, SAP Joule action bar (On-Demand).

Joule on Mobile Devices ‚Äì now for SAP Sales Cloud too

Joule has been available via SAP Mobile Start since Q1/2025 (as announced in this blog post), and is now also available directly from within the SAP Sales Cloud mobile app, supporting these three patterns:

  • Transactional: Joule can handle tasks like updating status, expected value, sales phase of opportunities, and more, directly within the chat interface.
  • Navigational: Joule can guide users to specific pages within the app based on their requests, such as directing them to where they can open a sales deal.
  • Informational: Joule can access documentation and knowledge bases to answer questions about company policies, and other relevant information, providing summaries and links to related resources.


Figure 10: Joule now available in the SAP Sales Cloud mobile app. Alt Text: Four images of iPhones showing (1) the Joule start page with suggestions for prompts such as ‚ÄúMy Opportunities‚Äù, (2) a card showing three opportunities, (3) the user prompted ‚ÄúTell me about 20653‚Äù, Joule shows a card with details about the Sales Deal and suggests further prompts such as ‚ÄúUpdate status‚Äù, (4) the user prompted ‚ÄúMy Accounts‚Äù, Joule shows a card with one account and suggests further prompts such as ‚ÄúShow Current Challenges‚Äù.

Joule Analytics Center For Analysing Usage

Knowing what users are using and how they are using it, as well as what they are not using, is a key ingredient of user research and key to constantly improving their user experience over time.

The Joule Analytics Center for Joule is now generally available, allowing customers to get precisely these kind of insights for Joule. It provide an interactive dashboard, where users can filter on:

  • Interaction type (Direct response, Scenario, Information retrieval, Slot filling, File upload)
  • Product name
  • Scenario name
  • Client type (desktop, mobile, Microsoft Copilot)
  • Date range.

The dashboard includes a summary and charts. To find out more, check out the documentation:

  • Joule Analytics Center.

Product-specific capabilities

In addition to the above generic capabilities, our products provide a large number of Joule skills for getting your work done more efficiently, as well as a handful of the new agents discussed above. For a comprehensive overview of Joule capabilities, including product-specific skills available today, here‚Äôs where to go:

  • Joule Capabilities (online documentation, starting with What‚Äôs New and then listing capabilities for each SAP product)

Customer-specific Agents: Agent Builder Available Now

Joule Agents significantly enhance the overall user experience, as opposed to the user interface, because the system will do a lot more for you based on your requests ‚Äì especially if you have multi-agents working on a complex workflow. As a result, the overall experience you have using SAP goes up a level, since you can get a lot done much more easily than before.

I‚Äôm pleased to say that the Agent builder in Joule Studio is now generally available. You can access it easily from SAP Build, as shown in Figure 3.


Figure 11: Create an AI Agent or a Joule Skill with SAP Build. Alt Text: Screenshot from SAP Build with the ‚ÄúCreate Project‚Äù pop-over giving the user four illustrated cards to choose ‚ÄúWhat would you like to build?‚Äù: ‚ÄúApplication‚Äù, ‚ÄúAutomated Process‚Äù, ‚ÄúAI Agent and Joule Skill (highlighted)‚Äù, ‚ÄúBusiness Site‚Äù.

For more information about building your own agents, have a look at this blog post by Michael Ameling,  watch the demo video and get details via the SAP Discovery Center:

  • Agent builder in Joule Studio is now generally available: Build your own Joule agents today!
  • Video: How to Build, Test and Deploy AI Agents with Agent Builder in Joule Studio (2:11 minutes)
  • SAP Discovery Center: Joule studio, agent builder.

Joule for Consultants: UX Enhancement (Prompt Guide and Library)

You can now ask Joule for Consultants to show Quick Links, resulting in an overview of available links: to the new prompt guide and prompt library, as well as links to what‚Äôs new and to open the console, as shown in Figure 12.


Figure 12: Quick Links in SAP Joule for Consultants. Alt Text: Image showing Joule in full screen mode, with the user prompt ‚ÄúQuick Links‚Äù at the top, followed by two cards side-by-side with illustrations: the left one showing hands typing on a keyboard, above a text explaining the prompt library and two links ‚ÄúShow Prompt Guide‚Äù and ‚ÄúOpen Prompt Library‚Äù. The right card shows an image of a console screen, a description of the console and two links ‚ÄúShow What‚Äôs New‚Äù and ‚ÄúOpen Console‚Äù.

The prompt guide gives advice on how to formulate effective prompts, including examples of well-formulated ones and less effective ones, as you can see in Figure 13.


Figure 13: The Prompt Guide in SAP Joule for Consultants. Alt Text: Screenshot of Joule in full-screen mode, with the chat area showing a card on the left with a list of recommendations, the first one ‚ÄúDefine Your Objective Clearly Basic Prompt‚Äù is highlighted. On the right a card with Prompt Details, with sections ‚ÄúEffective Example‚Äù, ‚ÄúLess Effective Style‚Äù, ‚ÄúDescription‚Äù, ‚ÄúType of Prompt‚Äù, and ‚ÄúRole‚Äù.

The prompt library lets you browse or search for pre-defined prompts relevant for common roles (such as Technology Consultant, Project Manager) or areas (such as UI5/Fiori Development, Security Best Practices, System Architecture Design). Each prompt comes with a brief description of its objective, an example of a similar prompt with a less effective style, and a longer description. The description explains why the suggested prompt is effective, gives hints on how to extend it to your needs, and also explains the shortcomings of the less effective example. Figure 14 shows the prompt library, with details for the selected prompt.


Figure 14: The Prompt Library in SAP Joule for Consultants. Alt Text: Screenshot of Joule for Consultant Console, with the two areas with a vertical separator that users can move left or right. On the left three columns of cards showing pre-defined prompts are shown, with ‚ÄúS/4HANA Legacy Integration Strategy‚Äù selected. On the right details of the prompt in sections ‚ÄúPrompt‚Äù, ‚ÄúLess Effective Style‚Äù, ‚ÄúObjective‚Äù, and ‚ÄúDescription‚Äù.

 Find out more in this blog post:

  • SAP Joule for Consultants: Listening, Learning, and Delivering.

To learn more about Joule for Consultants overall, watch this video or take the new learning journey:

  • Video: Joule for Consultants demo (12:02 minutes).
  • Learning Journey: Accelerating SAP Project Delivery Using SAP Joule for Consultants

Further information on Joule

If you want an overview of what‚Äôs new, or want to set up Joule in your landscape, have a look at these regular blog posts from Shanna Bauer, or look at the documentation:

  • From Hype to Hands-On: Level Up Your AI Skills This January (contains links to the posts from October 2025 onwards at the end).
  • Joule documentation (including What‚Äôs New, integration guide and more).
  • Joule overview (PDF file).

For an overview of what is planned, have a look at the road map for Joule in the SAP Road Map Explorer:

  • Joule Road Map.

 

SAP Build Work Zone

SAP Build Work Zone users and administrators benefit from these recent innovations ‚Äì note that when I refer to ‚ÄúAdvanced Edition‚Äù, that also covers SAP SuccessFactors Work Zone:

  • Advanced Edition: Now with Joule.
  • Advanced Edition: New menu experience.
  • Advanced Edition: Spaces and pages available.
  • Standard Edition: New shell bar, custom logos easier.

In addition to giving users concrete benefits in usability, these updates also contribute to our goal of providing a consistent user experience across the entire SAP Business Suite. They implement some of the design updates that I announced last year in my blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), with the goal to further increase consistency, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products ‚Äì no unexpected surprises.

Advanced Edition: Now with Joule

Having already been available in the standard edition, as well as SAP Start and SAP Mobile Start, Joule is now finally also available in the SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, as shown in Figure 15. You can find out more in this blog post, including information on how to set it up:

  • Joule is Now Integrated into SAP Build Work Zone - Advanced Edition


Figure 15: Joule in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. Alt Text: Screenshot showing the Joule start page bottom right over the advanced edition home page.

Advanced Edition: New Menu Experience

The new menu experience that is being introduced across the SAP Business Suite is now available for SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. It supports all three options specified by the SAP Design System, as you can see in Figure 16. Offering this ensures a consistent experience for accessing menus across all products in the suite.


Figure 16: New menu experience for SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. From left to right: collapse mode, full width mode, and drop-down mode. Alt Text: Three screenshot snippets showing a menu with entries (from top to bottom): Home, My Workspace, Recently Visitied Workspaces, Favorites, View All Workspaces, New Workspace, Applications, Knowledge Base. Each has its own icon; in collapse mode, only the icons are visible, for the others the text is visible too.

Owners of sites also benefit from the enhanced menu editor, shown in Figure 17. They can choose whether to use the default mode or whether to use the overlay mode. Also (not shown), they can configure which icon to use for each entry in the menu.


Figure 17: New menu editor for SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. Alt Text: Screenshot of the menu editor showing the menu items and options on the left, with a preview on the right.

Advanced Edition: Spaces and Pages Available

Business users now benefit from the Spaces and Pages design, as pioneered by the SAP Fiori launchpad, and available for the standard edition since 2023. Figure 18 shows an example of what this looks like.


Figure 18: Spaces and Pages in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. Alt Text: Screenshot of the home page of the advanced edition with spaces and pages: four spaces are listed in the top row, from left to right ‚ÄúEmployee Self Services‚Äù (selected), ‚ÄúFinance‚Äù, ‚ÄúNews‚Äù, and ‚ÄúProjects‚Äù. Below that the page shows five tiles and a large card ‚ÄúMy Goals‚Äù with a horizontal bar chart showing goal completion percentages for the 3 goals.

Content administrators of SAP Build Work Zone can activate Spaces and Pages - New Experience view mode in the site settings, then proceed to create spaces and pages manually, and add UI integration cards or tiles to each page. The new site experience displays spaces and pages that are federated from remote content providers side by side to spaces and pages that are created locally, as well as displaying pages that originate from a content package.

With this, SAP Mobile Start can now visualize spaces and pages, including UI integration cards, from all SAP Build Work Zone editions.

Find out more about the new site experience in the documentation, and about SAP Mobile Start support:

  • Documentation: New Experience View Mode
  • Blog post: Support of SAP Build Work Zone, advanced and much more: SAP Mobile Start V2.2 & 2.3 - Release Update

Standard Edition: New Shell Bar, Custom Logos Easier

New Shell Bar

We have standardized the shell bar for the SAP Business Suite, and now SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition has introduced a new compliant shell bar. For users the main difference is that the product name is now displayed next to the SAP Logo, as you can see on the left in Figure 19.

Some custom plugins or test automation which accesses elements in the shell bar, such as the user menu, may need to be adapted, because the old shell bar has been replaced by a web component implementation. For this reason, we currently only have the new shell bar switched on by default for new sites. For existing sites, we ask customers to test their plugins and automations in test sites first and then to enable the new shell. We currently plan to phase out the old shell header as follows, and as described in detail in KBA 3673380:

  1. Beginning Q2/2026 we plan to activate the new shell header for all sites, but customers have the option to opt out by switching it off temporarily.
  2. In Q3/2026, the new shell header will be the only option ‚Äì no opt-out any more.

Custom Logos Easier to Add

Customers can now replace the SAP log with a custom logo directly, without having to create a whole new visual theme. Often, customers only want to customize this one aspect, which now becomes much easier to do. Figure 19 shows an example, where the SAP logo (shown on the left) has been replaced by a Work Zone logo (shown on the right).


Figure 19: Replacing the SAP logo (shown on the left) with a custom logo (on the right). Alt Text: Screenshot snippet showing the top left of the page, with the logos visible top left.

 

SAP Mobile Start

The SAP Mobile Start 2.4 release brings a number of innovations. The one I would like to highlight here is SAP Document AI integration (shown below).

SAP Mobile Start 2.5 brings these innovations:

  • Support for Apple‚Äôs new Liquid Glass design language (shown below)
  • Additional filter option for To-Dos, allowing filtering by semantic groups defined in SAP Task Center.
  • A small but important detail: empty pages are not shown in the App screen anymore.

You can find links to more information about these two releases at the end of the section.

SAP Document AI Integration

With SAP Document AI now integrated, users can scan or upload documents directly from SAP Mobile Start, which are then processed by the SAP Document AI service. For example, if you need to scan and upload a quality certificate, you can start the upload process right from SAP Mobile Start, and the SAP Document AI service takes care of all necessary follow-on steps, such as extracting data and assigning them to the right business objects.  Figure 20 shows an example.


Figure 20: Document AI integrated in SAP Mobile Start. Alt Text: Three iPhone images: (1) the start page, with the card ‚ÄúSAP Document AI‚Äù listed as the first in ‚ÄúFavorites‚Äù; (2) a list of three possible document types, with ‚ÄúStandard Delivery Note‚Äù selected; (3) the camera showing an image of a delivery note, and a ‚ÄúSave (1)‚Äù button.

Apple‚Äôs Liquid Glass design language supported

With Liquid Glass, Apple has unified its platform design language across Apple‚Äôs ecosystem of products. Liquid Glass provides a much more dynamic and expressive user experience and complements the experience of latest Apple devices like the Apple iPhone 17.

The update gives users some concrete benefits beyond the ‚Äúlook‚Äù: you now get more space on the screen since the navigation bar collapses if it is not needed. Furthermore, the content scrolls below the navigation and header bar.


Figure 21: SAP Mobile Start on iPhone with the new Liquid Glass design. Alt Text: Two iPhone images showing how some of the content shines through icons that are in the foreground, such as the ‚ÄúStart‚Äù icon at the bottom over a ‚ÄúCustomer Factsheet‚Äù card.

To find out more about the above innovations as well as what is planned in our road map, have a look at:

  • SAP Mobile Start V2.4: SAP Document AI integration and much more. Release Update.
  • SAP Mobile Start V2.5 - Release update brings UX and To-Do enhancements.
  • SAP Mobile Start Road Map.

 

Continued soon‚Ä¶

I hope you enjoyed this first part, covering cross-product UX services. I will post part two soon, covering a large number of UX innovations just released with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 and SAP Fiori launchpad.

Best regards,
Stefania

entry.title: Configuring SAP GRDC Connection to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud ‚Äî Step-by-Step Guide Part 1
entry.content:
Table of contents

  1. Introduction
  2. High-level architecture and token flow
  3. Prerequisites
  4. Step 1 ‚Äî Provision and configure IAS (Identity Authentication Service)
  5. Step 2 ‚Äî Configure trust between BTP subaccount and IAS
  6. Step 3 ‚Äî Prepare the S/4HANA Cloud side (Users and Communication)
  7. Step 4 ‚Äî Prepare the BTP Side (Users and Destinations)
  8. Step 5 ‚Äî Deploy & test the GRDC app against S/4HANA Cloud
  9. How to request Consulting
  10. References & further reading

1. Introduction

Integrating SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) apps with S/4HANA Public Cloud securely requires configuring identity, trust, and connectivity so API calls from the app are authenticated and authorized in S/4HANA and vice versa. The Group Reporting Data Collection app (GRDC) is a SAP BTP-hosted solution commonly used to collect financial and non-financial data for S/4HANA Group Reporting. This guide focuses on a straightforward set up of the technical connection. SAP recommends using Principal Propagation which means it forwards the end-user identity from across the different layers to S/4HANA that will apply user-based authorization.

 Goals:

  • Configure IAS as the IdP for authentication first, then add a Custom IdP
  • Configure trust (metadata exchange) between IAS and BTP
  • Prepare the S/4HANA Public Cloud Communication Scenarios
  • Create destinations in BTP to call S/4HANA Public Cloud Communication Scenarios
  • Test GRDC Apps
  • Describe Common Errors and Pitfalls (Part 2 of this Blog)

2. High-level architecture & token flow

Overview:

Applications in SAP BTP do not store user information. Instead, the applications redirect the authentication to an Identity Provider. 

For SAP BTP, there are several options for authentication , of which  SAP ID Service and SAP Cloud Identity Authentication service (IAS) come with a BTP subscription. SAP ID service is the default identity provider for both platform users and business users (in applications) at SAP BTP. You can start using it without further configuration.

We strongly recommend that you configure your custom tenant of SAP Cloud Identity Services as the identity provider and connect SAP Cloud Identity Services to your own corporate identity provider. This topic needs to be adressed before the project, for testing purposes you can also start with the Default Identity Provider from SAP BTP .

Common flows used for SAP Group Reporting Data Collection:

  • OAuth2 SAML Bearer Assertion (OAuth2SAMLBearerAssertion): the BTP app requests token and uses SAML assertion to get an S/4HANA access token.
 

This picture should show the high level architecture, the yellow points refer to steps in the Administration Guide which have a different numbering than this Blog  Source: SAP Help

3. Prerequisites

Before starting the configuration, verify the following prerequisites. You will need possibly different personas with different roles and access. 

  • SAP BTP global account and a subaccount with Cloud Foundry where GRDC is provisioned. The Subscription has the correct entitlements.
  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud:  Scopes are activated for SAP Group Reporting
  • The following scopes need to be activated for Group Reporting: 1SG  https://me.sap.com/processnavigator/globalSearch/1SG.
  • For GRDC Integration activate Scope 287 https://me.sap.com/processnavigator/globalSearch/287
  • Setting Up Users S/4HANA Public Cloud, see this blog User Management in a nutshell for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS) tenant (trial or productive) ‚Äî or access to the customer‚Äôs IAS tenant.
  • Roles and permissions of users doing configuration steps:
    • BTP subaccount: Org & Space admin or subaccount admin to configure trust and destinations
    • S/4HANA Public Cloud: Admin role that can create Communication Arrangements and Communication Systems
    • S/4HANA Public Cloud: Admin role that can create Business Roles from Templates
    • S/4HANA Public Cloud: Admin role that can create Business Users and assign Roles
    • IAS admin (Custom IdP Admin): ability to configure identity providers, trust and user stores
  • Basic knowledge of OAuth2 / SAML concepts and SAP BTP Destination service eg. by BTP Onboarding Training

4. Step 1 ‚Äî Provision and configure IAS (Identity Authentication Service)

With each SAP BTP provision there is a default identity tenant included which has also delivered users to start. Global Accounts come connected to SAP ID Service at the Identity Provider. However, it is recommended to set up a custom IdP for identity authentication via IAS. (Identity Authentication Service). For many customers, business users might be stored in corporate identity providers.

SAP recommends using SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Authentication Service (IAS)  as a hub.

  1. Create or access an IAS tenant using SAP BTP cockpit.
  2. Choose Establish Trust.
  3. The Configure Tenant wizard opens.
  4. Choose the SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant and choose Next. The identity providers listed are the SAP Cloud Identity Services tenants associated with your customer ID

5. Step 2.1 ‚Äî Configure trust between BTP subaccount and IAS

Settings on the Identity Provider

Configuring an IdP to supply identity to applications on a subaccount is basically a two-step process to setup a mutual Trust via an exchange of SAML metadata artifacts.

As a first step, go to BTP Cockpit and take the SAML metadata from the Subaccount that was provisioned.

The 'Trust Configuration' section has a button to download the SAML Metadata. Click on this button and locally save the XML representation of the metadata file.

Now, head over to the Administration page of your IAS tenant to configure the artifact that was downloaded. 

The 2 important sections here that need to be configured are

a) Configurations to setup the SAML Service Provider (SAP BTP)

b) Subject Name identifier (which is a user profile attribute to uniquely identify and authenticate users between applications)

Import the SAML metadata file downloaded in the previous step

Choose a subject name identifier that is known and provided in the IAS/IdP on BTP and on S/4HANA, public edition Side.

The choice significantly impacts authentication success, as any mismatch between the SAML assertion's NameID and the S/4HANA user identifier will result in authentication failure. The authentication type used for the GRDC connection will be OAuth SAML Bearer Assertion .

Where as BTP has several possibilities (user ID, loginame or email) , from S/4HANA Public Edition side there are only two:

S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition expects the Subject Name Identifier has to be set to "Login Name" or "Email address": Do not use user ID.  

If you use Login Name as subject name identifier, it will match the User Name of the Business User on S/4HANA Public Cloud side with Login name of the User on BTP side.

If you use email as subject name identifier, it will match the email of the Business Useron S/4HANA Public Cloud side with email of the User on BTP side.

We will create users on BTP side and S/4HANA Public Cloud side in Step 6 where this information is maintained. After that in step 7 the technical link will be configured in the BTP destination. For now, you need to decide which of the two options you go for in alignment with your overall IDP strategy for user logon.

5. Step 2.2 ‚Äî Configure trust between BTP subaccount and Custom IdP

When you have set up a custom IdP and the same way as for the default IAS you have now these possibilities for trust configuration:

Flag this custom Identity Provider as ‚ÄûAvailable for User logon‚Äú 

Possible Pitfall: Several Identity Provider have a Flag set for ‚ÄúAvailable for User Logon‚Äù. Choose only one Identity Provider to be available for logon.

-Add test users to the IdP or connect an external user store (e.g., corporate IdP via SAML or SCIM provisioning via IPS).-

 

6. Step 3.1. ‚Äî Prepare the S/4HANA Public Cloud side with Business Users and Business Roles

  1. Log into your SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant with an admin role.
  2. Enter the App Maintain Business Roles. Create a Custom Role by copying a delivered SAP Role
 
Do this for the following Roles for our first testing. After that you will need to refine the role usage depending on the business requirements.

 

SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR_GRP

SAP_BR_GL_ACCOUNTANT_GRP

Now you have created Group Reporting Data Collection related Roles

Next step is to create business users via the app: Maintain Business Users and assign the created roles.

Especially take care of providing the same information about user propagation then configured in the step 2.1. by inserting the email address in the provided field.

If you have decided for email as subject name identifier, here the E-Mail needs to be inserted. If you have opted for Login Name, the User Name that is chosen needs to correspond the BTP Login Name.
You see as well User ID which would be available. Do not use User ID for user propagation as it is a technical name! However this CB* User would be needed for SAP Customer Support Cases to provide for SAP Support or visible in System Administration apps, both are not needed now. 

6. Step 3.2. ‚Äî Prepare the S/4HANA Public Cloud side with Communication System, Arrangement  and Communication User

Now go on creating the communication scenarios by creating Communication User, Communication System and Communication Arrangement.

1. Create a Communication User for GRDC

 

 
This is straightforward. You can give the user a meaningful name corresponding to GRDC or referring to the communication arrangement 0241 as there might be several ones connection different Products and Systems. You see that the user ID starts with CC other then the Business User which start with CB. This user ID starting with CC can be selected in Communication Traces later for Troubleshooting.
Note down the User name.

2. Open Communication Management ‚Üí Communication Systems

3. Create a new Communication System for BTP integration:

  • Hostname: use the full qualified hostname that you obtain from the BTP cockpit . Select the Subdomain name and add it to this FQDN (fully qualified domain name): [subdomain_name].grdc-sap.cfapps.[region_name].hana.ondemand.com -> Here ccon-XXX.grdc-sap.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com

 
S/4HANA Public Cloud side:
 
Beware of typos, there is no input validation check!
 
Still in the Communication System we come to the place where we link the S4/HANA system trust with the BTP sub-account. To set up this parameter, we need to download the certificate of our GRDC BTP sub-account.

 

Go to BTP Cockpit ->

Go to the BTP account. 

  • From the left column, choose Destination-> Destination Trust. 
  • Choose Export  -> Download file to a location

 

S/4HANA Cloud side:

Go the the Communication System in S/4HANA Public Cloud

  • In the Communication System under OAuth 2.0 Identity Provider, select the Enabled checkbox.
  • Upload the downloaded file in the OAuth 2.0 Identity Provider section.
  • The OAuth 2.0 SAML Issuer must match the Common Name (CN) of the Signing Certificate Subject.
Possible Pitfalls:
 
The Oauth 2.0 SAML Issuer Field above should contain the value of CN from certificate.

 

BUT IMPORTANT: it should not contain the leading letter "CN=" !

 For Inbound and Outbound Communication: Enter the previously created communication user and use the generated password.

 

Click: SAVE

 4. Create a Communication Arrangement (Communication Management ‚Üí Communication Arrangements): Click on ‚ÄûNew‚Äú and choose SAP_COM_0241

Add the communication system that you created in step 2 in the mandatory field ‚ÄûCommunication system‚Äú.

It is adding already all relevant services for Inbound (if BTP calls S/4HANA)

 

And Outbound (if S/4HANA calls BTP)

The Inbound Communication user will be added as well from the Communication system. ‚Äî if BTP calls S/4HANA. It should not be changed.

 

 
The Outbound user (S/4HANA calls BTP ) was also taken from the Communication system and should not be changed. The authentication method should be User ID and Password.
In the section: "Common data" note down the  "API -URL " for later use in the BTP Destination.

 

 
You see here as well that the Service URL was taken from the Field ‚ÄûHost‚Äú in the Communication System. 
 
If there is no slash "/" at the end, add it in all fields.

 

In the Inbound User Section:

Click on ‚ÄûOAuth 2.0 Details‚Äù (these appear once you have saved)

The Token Service URL is important and needs to be saved for later use in the BTP Destination.
 
Now you have finished the S/4HANA Cloud side.

 

You would need the following information to proceed with the BTP side:

Note down the S/4HANA API base URL and the Token service URL in the arrangement from the OAuth 2.0 Details.

7. Step 4 ‚Äî Prepare the BTP Side (Users and Destinations)

Step 4.1.  Create Roles and and assign Roles to Users

Go to SAP BTP Cockpit -> Subaccount -> Role collection -> Create 

Use an own name e.g. GRDC Roles and assign all template roles.

Here is a list of Roles that are enough for testing. Later a more refined authorization concept is needed. Note that roles must be assigned on SAP BTP and on SAP S/4HANA Side respectively. They servce different purposes and the assignement is mandatory.

Go the the left menue of the SAP BTP Cockpit to "Users".

Create Users , in our example you have to enter the User name via email, the Identity Provider which supplies the user information and an E-mail address:

This entries may vary according to the setup of your Identity Provider.

Save and go inside the User configuration to:  Role Collection and assign the previously created Role collection.

Now these users are set. 

Step 4.2 .  Create BTP Destinations

A destination lets your BTP app call S/4HANA endpoints securely.

In SAP BTP Cockpit ‚Üí Subaccount ‚Üí Connectivity ‚Üí Destinations click New Destination.

1. Destination:  Name it S4HanaCConsoEndpoint  (standard name, exact spelling)

GRDC uses ‚ÄúOAuth SAML Bearer Assertion‚Äù as authentication type. Fill in the details like explained in this tables:

 
 
 
 
 
 
In the BTP Cockpit it looks like this:
There is now an extra section of SAML Properties that were previously in the section ‚ÄûAdditional Properties‚Äúwith Drop Down Menu

 

Here is the technical link name identifier for user authentication between SAP BTP and S/4HANA Public Cloud
 
nameIdFormat must have one of two values , if it has no entry that as a default the format "unspecified" is taken. 
 
If in the IAS admin page  the "Subject Name Identifier" was set to Email Address, then the "Default Name ID Format" should be "Email".
- urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:1.1:nameid-format:emailAddress

If in the IAS admin page the "Subject Name Identifier" was set to Login Name, then the "Default Name ID Format" should be "Unspecified". 

- urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:1.1:nameid-format:unspecified 
 
Verify spelling!

Please doublecheck in this documentation as this setting depends on your overall IdP policy  https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/configure-subject-name-identifier-sent-to-application

Save and wait 5 Minutes before Check Connection as there is a 5 minute cache when saving new configuration.

Checking the connection with the ‚ÄûCheck‚Äú button of the destination only means that the S/4HANA host is technically reachable. It will not check principal propagation! This can only be done by entering the GRDC Apps.

 2.  Second BTP Destination: S4HanaCConsoEndpoint_API  (standard name, exact spelling)

Use the S/4HANA communication user and password created for this destination.

Save and wait 5 Minutes before Check Connection as there is a 5 minute cache when saving new configuration.

Checking the connection with the ‚ÄûCheck‚Äú button of the destination only means that the S/4HANA host is technically reachable. It will not check principal propagation! This can only be done by entering the GRDC Apps

8. Step 5 ‚Äî Deploy & test the GRDC app against S/4HANA Cloud

  1. Go to the Fiori Launchpad, there should now be visible the SAP Group Reporting and SAP Group Reporting Data Collection related apps  and open the Group Reporting App ‚ÄûEnter Global Parameters‚Äú. The business user needs to have the global parameters set before calling GRDC Apps. This means that SAP Group Reporting needs to be set up but you can set delivered entries for Period, Time, Version and Chart Of Accounts. Save.
  2. Open the GRDC  APP Define packages  and log in with your business user ‚Äî you should authenticate via IAS/IDP. Choose Manage Forms or Manage Packages to test the Logon and authentication,

     

  3. Run a sample Form in Enter Package Data that requires reading/writing data to S/4HANA

9. How to request consulting

  1. Should you require assistance with the setup and configuration SAP Group Reporting Data Collection, we recommend consulting. Contact your SAP Account via this KBA 2626344‚ÄØ- Who is the SAP Account Manager for my company? 

12. References & further reading

  • SAP Help Portal ‚Äî SAP Group Reporting and Data Collection
  • Administration Guide
  • SAP Help Portal ‚Äî SAP BTP: Destinations and Connectivity
  • SAP Help Portal ‚Äî SAP Identity Authentication Service documentation
  • SAP Community: Articles about S/4HANA Public Cloud Group Reporting and Group Reporting Data Collection
  • Onboarding Material for BTP

Part 2: Troubleshooting Logon Errors ->  Coming soon..

entry.title: Understanding Known Limitations of Calculations Feature in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
entry.content:
Overview of the Collective KBA

With SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), users can create flexible reporting through the use of 'story calculation', however, it is important to note that not all story calculations are created equally; there are limitations, set by the design of story calculations, which may impact the way in which the calculation interacts with other variables, such as filters, hierarchies, drill states, types of data, and data model structure.
In order to ensure you understand how the calculation functions, we have put together an extensive resource that describes all of these conditions in detail.

3702507 ‚Äî Known Limitations and By-Design Behaviors of Calculation Features in SAP Analytics Cloud (Collective KBA)

The aim of the Combined KBA is to provide a detailed perspective regarding the limitations and anticipated performance of the calculations that occur on the Story level in SAC. This will provide a way for users to recognize where some functions/operations, etc. may not work as they expect due to the way in which the calculation engine has been designed.

Purpose of the Collective KBA

The intent of the KBA is to present a transparent overview of the calculation boundaries in SAC so that report designers and analytics teams can plan and validate their work with realistic expectations. It outlines:

  • where specific functions are supported,

  • where particular data types are restricted,

  • how calculations respond to filtering and drill operations,

  • and which behaviors are determined by the design of the underlying analytical engine.

The KBA only provides clarification of capabilities. It does not offer alternative approaches, workarounds, or modeling techniques. The main goal is to make these types of limitations clear and easily accessible.

Looking ahead

SAP will continue enhancing Story Calculations and the overall SAC experience. As features evolve, this collective KBA will serve as a living reference‚Äîupdated as new capabilities are delivered or design boundaries change.

If a feature is required for business operations, user may submit an enhancement request through the standard SAP Influence channel. Refer to the KBA: 2424376 - How to create an enhancement request for SAP Analytics Cloud?

Your feedback, questions, and real-world scenarios are part of what helps shape this clarity. If you encounter behaviors that feel inconsistent or unclear, please continue to raise them. They help us improve not only the product but the guidance we provide.

entry.title: SAP MIRO tolerance exceeded hard error instead of blocked for payment
entry.content:
Hi all,

We have a requirement in MIRO (Invoice Verification) regarding price variance tolerance (PP key).

Current standard behavior:

  • When the invoice price exceeds PO price beyond the PP tolerance limits (OMR6), MIRO posts the invoice with a warning and marks it as Blocked for Payment.

Our requirement:

  • We need to prevent invoice posting completely when the PP tolerance is exceeded (i.e. trigger a hard error, not a warning).

Business scenario:

  • We post service invoices without GR/Service Entry (no 3-way match).
  • Therefore, AP users can over-enter invoice amounts and later release invoice blocks.
  • For compliance reasons, we must not allow invoice price > PO price for these cases.

Question:

  • Is it possible in standard to switch PP tolerance exceed from ‚Äúwarning + blocked for payment‚Äù to a hard error?
  • If not, which BAdI / user-exit is recommended to implement this behavior in MIRO (e.g., MRM_HEADER_CHECK, MRM_ITEM_CHECK, etc.)?
  • Which structures or parameters in the BAdI provide the link between the MIRO invoice item and the underlying PO item?"

 

Best regards,

Often I receive questions on extensibility possibilities for workflows / Inboxes. Here is an overview of the BAdIs for flexible and SAP Business Workflow. It is only to take a look on possibilities to extend workflow capabilities related to ABAP Platform Workflow, Workflow Inboxes. I'm not claiming it's complete; it is not aligned with SAP Documentation, some information (SAP internal, some are not recommended any more, etc.) missing and it's just not well structured/sorted. For improvements please comment. I will be working on this list from time to time.

Item

SWF_PROCESS_VISIBILITY_CONTXTSWF_PROC_VISIBILITY_CONTXT_DEF

Lets the customer define and enhance the context which is pushed to Process Visibility

SWF_PROCESS_VISIBILITY_CONTXTSWF_PROC_VISIBILITY_CONTXT_RUN

Lets the customer define and enhance the context which is pushed to Process Visibility

SWF_INBOX_ACTION_PROCESSINGSWF_CHECK_ACTION_ALLOWEDProvides additional custom logic upon triggering inbox action
SWF_WI_FORWARD_AGENTS_GETSWF_FORWARD_AGENTS_GET_INTERNFilter agents for forwarding (internal use only)
SWF_WI_FORWARD_AGENTS_GETSWF_FORWARD_AGENTS_GET_CUSTOMFilter agents for forwarding (customer's extension)
SWF_UTL_HOME_ACTIVESWF_HOME_AVAILABLEWorkflow: Check availability of workflow home objects
RSM_ES_STATIC_RULERSM_BADI_STATIC_RULEBAdI can be implemented by SAP as well OP customers to find the right agents (via Responsibility Management) for the task

entry.title: Re: What is a SAP Credly badge?

Hi @TMNielsen, 

Credly is a digital credential network, where for instance digital learning, courses and cerfitication badges can be earned and managed. Like a digital library of badges you have earned across different web properties.

entry.title: Re: Why two different buttons for our own account?
entry.content:
Hi @Jelena_Perfiljeva, 

I am so sorry for not getting back to you sooner. 

The short explanation to the two different buttons, is that they link to two different profiles that serves different purposes. It is on our radar to make the differences clearer in the navigation. 
1. The icon in the main navigation bar takes you to your SAP Profile. This profile is an overarching SAP profile to all SAP web properties, similar to people.sap.com that was used on the previous platform. 

2. The second navigation bar will take you to your Community platform profile, your content published in the community and the community platform specific settings. 

Kind regards,
Anne

entry.title: Re: Process Journal Entries to SAP B1 via Service Layer
entry.content:
Dear @dimtriant ,

While I understand you want to use service layer for this, the ideal way to handle this, is importing a file via DTW and you can use the sample file provided by DTW samples in its install path to create your own excel file since i assume you must have this data in a file somewhere! 

If you are adamant about using B1SL, then make sure you use $batch 50-200 journal entries per $batch (depending on average line size). Personally i'd avoid this. Service Layer doesn't give you a convenient way to wrap it all in one big transaction so think about the retry logic in terms of failures and how you would handle those cases.

Now if this is, lets say, a repeatable process you have to do yearly then i would write up a process that runs this carefully and logs the results with failures/successes or adds some reference to the line of your file to be able to intervene for those that might fail to import. 


Sincerely, 
@ens_

entry.title: Re: How We Retired almost 10% of Our Custom Code (And Counting) ‚Äì Lessons from Real Life
entry.content:
For the usage tracking in SAP ERP I use ST03N. I guess ST03n is customizable. In our system it is set up to save the last 3 months workload, so to get a full year I have to run an extract every 3 months.

I think the "Orphaned Includes Strategy" should also consider function moduls, classes, data dictionary objects, .... - not just include files.

I don't know how you use AI to identify orphans, but I think a full cleaning will probably require a lot of manual work.

If for example you delete a program that stores som data in a z-table and after this you have 3 programs reading data from the z-table, but no programs updating it. Then a full cleaning would also mean deletion of the z-table and deletion or cleaning of the 3 programs reading the z-table.

And the deletion of the z-table may create orphaned data elements, search helps, data domains and ...

@BaerbelWinkler you say selection variants should be deleted first, but in my system (ERP 6.0) the problem is the opposite. When deleting  the program, the selection variant are automatically deleted,. If we for some reason should need to reverse the deletion of the program, we can restore it from version management, but the selection variants are gone forever.

Best regards
Thomas

entry.title: Need BAdI for Auto-Setting Validity Date in Sales Enquiries
entry.content:
Hi,

I have a requirement for sales enquiries (document type IN) where:

  1. Auto-Set Validity Date
    • When the enquiry is saved, if the Validity Date is empty, it should be automatically set to 30 days from the Enquiry Date.
  2. Freeze Item Quantity After Validity Expiry
    • If the current date is greater than the Validity Date:
      • User cannot change Item Quantity.
      • Other fields should remain editable.
  3. Restriction
    • This logic should apply only to Enquiries and must not affect Sales Orders or Quotations.

I have tried searching for a BAdI in SE18/SE19 and checked the following standard BAdIs, but none of them seem suitable:

BADI_SD_SALES, BADI_SD_SALES_BASIC,  BADI_SD_CM, BADI_LAYER, ADDR_PRINTFORM_SHORT, BADI_SD_SALES_ITEM, CHECK_COBL_ADDON, EHS_DG_002, ATP_PUBLISH_RESULTS, BADI_SD_TO_FM, BADI_ISPS_GRANT, DIP_UPDATE_FKDAT

Could anyone suggest which BAdI or enhancement point I can use to implement this requirement for sales enquiries only?

Thank you in advance!

entry.title: UI5 MCP Server Got Extended for UI Integration Cards Generation
entry.content:
Following recent announcement for the release and availability of the UI5 MCP server, we are pleased to announce that the UI5 MCP Server now supports the development of Integration Cards. In its latest version ‚Äì v0.2.1 ‚Äì it includes three new tools dedicated to Integration Cards. These tools assist Large Language Models (LLMs) in creating new Integration Cards from scratch or editing existing ones, following the best practices for card development.

Infuse Creativity Into Your Integration Cards

The updated UI5 MCP Server version v.0.2.1 enhances card development with AI Agents like Cline. Fostering creativity and efficiency, this approach makes it easy for both developers and non-developers to create Integration Cards smoothly.

Usage of the UI5 MCP Server in Cline.

 

Why Use the UI5 MCP Server for Integration Cards Development?

The reasons for initially using UI5 MCP Server are similarly applicable to developing Integration Cards:

  • LLMs might lack information on the latest best practices and APIs recommended for Integration Cards development.
  • LLMs might suggest using the properties of Integration Cards or APIs that are not available in your project's version or have been marked as deprecated.
  • Scaffolding can help agents kickstart new projects faster and with established patterns, saving token costs.

and furthermore:

  • Encouraging the use of cards of type Declarative to make the card also compatible with Mobile Native platforms.
  • Providing specific knowledge for each card type to the LLMs, such as the available chart types in Analytical cards, and enabling the LLMs to suggest the best chart type for your data.
  • And more‚Ä¶

Tools

  1. Best practice guidance for your agent: get_integration_cards_guidelines
  2. Scaffolding a new Integration Card: create_integration_card
  3. Validating the Card‚Äôs manifest: run_manifest_validation

Setup & Use 

Install the UI5 MCP Server v.0.2.1 in your AI agent, as described here. Once this version or later is installed, your AI Agent should automatically gain access to the new tools. Once you define your prompt for generating a Card the AI Agent will offer you as first step to run the get_integration_cards_guidelines, then will scaffold the very coding project with dynamically created Card, and finally will run the manifest schema validation tool. Enjoy your Card! 

What‚Äôs Next?

We plan to further enhance the existing tools to handle more complex scenarios, such as creating or editing child cards, pagination in list and table cards, a more advanced configuration editor for the generated card, and more.

entry.title: S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 Fully-Activated Appliance custom installation
entry.content:
This blog covers installation of (1) SAP S/4HANA server and (2) SAP NW JAVA / ADS server as shown in the graphic below. The installation is based on file restore and is different from the standard installs using SWPM.

Please refer to S/4HANA SQUARE ONE for other blogs

In this blog the procedure is simplified for hostname change and SID change. Also if you want to change instance number the command, screens show where you can change the instance number. This would make sense if your network cannot accommodate the unique hostname and SID. Also if it is a more permanent installation you may like to change SID and hostname.

If you want to do standard installation with no change in hostname and sid please refer to other blog In this blog the procedure is simplified for standard installation with NO HOSTNAME OR SID CHANGE. The advantage with this is that you don't have to do many of the steps related to SID change and it does make sense if you will be installing the instance temporarily.

This blog is based on a fresh installation of SUSE Linux for SAP OS without having any previous SAP instances created and deleted. I did not have to pre install hostagent, etc. There are mount points/links to be setup as shown in the right place in the directory structure. The steps in the guides provided with SAP Note 2041140 could be used as a reference in case there are issues specific to your environment. Just follow the steps below to install both systems shown in red square below:

Please find below the main note for ordering the appliance:
2041140 - Order an SAP pre-assembled Best Practices software appliance (as partner or customer)

PART1: SOFTWARE DOWNLOAD

Please download the software media from https://me.sap.com/softwarecenter
INSTALLATIONS & UPGRADES => By Alphabetical Index (A-Z) => S => SAP S/4HANA => SAP S/4HANA 2025 => S/4HANA FULLY-ACTIVATED APPLIANCE => SAP S/4HANA 2025 FA APPL

On SAP S/4HANA Server, download the 51059242_1 to 51059242_5  files and SWPM20SP22_5-80003424.SAR (or later).

On SAP NW JAVA / ADS server, download the 51059242_5, SWPM10SP45_4-20009701.SAR and 51050829_JAVA_part 1 & 2 - NW 7.5 Java based SW Comp.

PART2: INSTALL SAP S/4HANA

STEP 1: PREPARE SYSTEM Prepare Linux Server as below for the appliance. The values in Used column below show the minimum size needed. For /sapmnt provide min 30GB, /hana/data space - min 500GB, /hana/log min 120GB. I have used /sapmedia - 200GB temporary separate mount that can be removed later.

Plan the change of SID, hostname, instance number. Please refer to the notes below for reserved SIDs SAP Note 1979280 - Reserved SAP System Identifiers (SAPSID) with Software Provisioning Manager and hostnames SAP Note 611361 - Hostnames of SAP ABAP Platform servers
The table below shows standard SID and hostnames and what we are changing it to.

The /etc/hostname and /etc/host file is below. If you are changing hostname for db and sap add the standard and new hostname for DB but for SAP only provide new hostname. Also for J2E include the new hostname only as this is on separate instance. The standard hostname can be removed later as shown in the steps below. Please note that it has

STEP 2: EXTRACT FILES Extract files 51059242_*  in /sapmedia

sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_1.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_2.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_3.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_4.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_5.ZIP

Allow approx 2 hours for extraction.

We will install Central system with DB and App on same server. Please move all *.tgz-* files (from 51059242_1 to 51059242_4) to /sapmedia/51059242_1/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_1

cd /sapmedia/51059242_1/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_1
mv /sapmedia/51059242_2/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_2/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51059242_3/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_3/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51059242_4/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_4/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51059242_5/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_5/*.tgz-*   .

In the next step we will extract the above *.tgz files but please note the directories size is as follows so you can provide ample space:

Please use command below to extract the database related archives:

sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia/# cd 51059242_1/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_1

cat dblog.tgz-* | tar --numeric-owner -zpxvf - -C /

Similarly extract the remaining files:

cat dbexe.tgz-* | tar --numeric-owner -zpxvf - -C /
cat dbdata.tgz-* | tar --numeric-owner -zpxvf - -C /

It takes about an hour for extraction.

Below two Application related archives may be extracted on a separate app server for distributed installation. These files will be extracted under /sapmnt/S4H and /usr/sap/S4H so if you are changing the SID, then you will have to first extract to SID-S4H and then create links to your own SID like S4D

Then extract the files:
sid-hdd-s4d:/usr/sap #cd 51059242_1/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_1
cat usrsap_s4h.tgz-* | tar --numeric-owner  -zpxvf - -C /
cat sapmnt_s4h.tgz-* | tar --numeric-owner  -zpxvf - -C /

STEP 3: GET PASSWORDS Download the file below and open the file in Internet Explorer to note passwords:
/sapmedia/51059242_1/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_5/SAP_Software_Appliance.xml


Follow this procedure as it is a known issue, please refer SAP Note 2082466 - Known Issues in SAP HANA Platform Lifecycle Management (HDBLCM)  (Issue# 69)

cd /hana/shared/HDB/HDB02/vhcalhdbdb
rm .daemon.ini.swp

vi daemon.ini
Edit section [localsecurestore] to change instances = 0

STEP 4: REGISTER DATABASE 

The HANA DB hdblcm register_rename_system command will rename the filesystem for you according to the new target SID for Hana database instance. HDB => HDD.

Please ensure groupid=1000 is free and groupid=79 are free. Use SAP Note 3686516 for troubleshooting.

Execute HANA database specific steps as below:

sid-hdd-s4d: ##/hana/shared/HDB/hdblcm/hdblcm --action=register_rename_system  --groupid=1000 --lss_groupid=79

TIP: Places where you need to enter data is indicated, rest all are default options. Please note hdblcm now includes rename database host and a separate step with command to rename db host (hdblcm --action=rename_system --hostmap=vhcalhdbdb=vhcalhdddb) is not required. Also a separate step to rename mount points (hdblcm --action=register_rename_system) is not required.

This should bring up the database processes as below

sid-hdd-s4d: #/usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 02 -function GetProcessList

TIP: At this point it is necessary to install the HANA database license as the database will be started in restricted mode.

STEP 5: EXTRACT SWPM Extract SWPM in folder /install. Use the SAPCAR already available to extract.

sid-hdd-s4d:/install #/sapmnt/S4D/exe/uc/linuxx86_64/SAPCAR -xvf /sapmedia/SWPM20SP22_5-80003424.SAR

STEP 6: RENAME SAP SYSTEM Rename instance using sapinst

sid-hdd-s4d:/install # ./sapinst SAPINST_ENFORCE_CRL=false SAPINST_USE_HOSTNAME=vhcals4dci SAPINST_GUI_HOSTNAME=vhcals4dci 

Copy below URL into chrome browser to start sapinst rename process:

https://sid-hdd-s4d.dummy.nodomain:4237/sapinst/docs/index.html

In SAPINST select System Rename => Standard System => SAP System Rename

At screen SAP System Parameters enter Source System S4H and Target System S4D:
Click on Next.

At the screen Prerequisite Checker Results accept or fix the Prerequisite check results.
Click on Next. No if you don't want to repeat the test

At the screen SAP Instance Parameters accept or change the Target System Instance Numbers.
Click on Next.

At the screen SAP HANA Database Connectivity enter Instance Number 02(or changed number) and Password Appliance__1234. Click on Next.

If you don't install HANA DB license you will get error below. Install license using HANA Studio and continue. License is required if there is a database SID change..

At the screen SAP HANA Database Parameter you can change Schema User , DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM password. Please note it is also optional to change the schema user SAPHANADB password along with DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM users.

At the screen Database Schema accept schema SAPHANADB password and confirm Schema password Xxxxxxxn click on Next.

At the screen Rename Tenant Database click on Next

At the screen Secure Storage for Database Connection select HANA Secure User tore (hdbuserstore) click on Next 

At the screen Operating System Users accept master password or enter password Xxxxxxxn
At the screen Secure Storage Key Generation accept radio button ‚Äì Individual Key (Recommended for Productive Systems) On the Next
At next screen Warning click OK
At the screen DNS Domain Name checkmark Set FQDN for SAP System and enter domain name dummy.nodomain Click on Next
At the screen Install License Key keep unchecked Install License Key. Click on Next
TIP: It is much easier to install the license by providing the file than doing it later through the application.
At next screen Cleanup of Encryption Key checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next
At next screen Cleanup of Operating System Users checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next
Here is the Parameter Summary Click on Next to confirm and begin the installation.

TIP: In case you get this ERROR:

(1) Error occurs when executing command 'changekey' using the command line tool 'rsecssfx'.

RESOLUTION: Follow SAP Note 2800204 - SSFX-0362: Value file "-" does not start with the UTF-8 byte order mark

Ensure the environment variable LC_CTYPE of the user running sapinst is set as LC_CTYPE=en_US.
Stop the current sapinst and restart it. Continue with the existing option.

(2) You may get Warning below for rename of profile parameter. Found possible references to the source system in the profile directory of the target system /sapmnt/S4D/profile 

After sapinst process is finished you can manually start the SAP instance S4D

sid-hdd-s4d:/install # /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 01 -function StartSystem ALL
sid-hdd-s4d:/install # /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 00 -function StartSystem ALL

After instance is started and confirmed you can delete the sapmedia folder and remove temporary links to S4H as well as temporary hostnames.

Standard users are as follows:
HANA DB ‚Äì Instance 02 SYSTEM /<Master Password> or as you changed in above
Web Dispatcher access : bpinst/Welcome1

STEP 7: POST STEPS Follow steps from guide attached to SAP Note 2041140 - First Steps for on-premise installations.pdf => Section 5 Technical Post-deployment Activities

Adapt HANA connections in DBACOCKPIT (nothing was required to be done here).

Host name / port in table HTTPURLLOC using tcode httpurlloc

Adapt RFC Connections

ABAP connections:
‚Ä¢ LOCAL_RFC
‚Ä¢ S4DCLNT100, S4DCLNT200, S4DCLNT400
‚Ä¢ S4D_RFC

HTTP connections:
‚Ä¢ ADS (pointing to the JAVA server after PART3: INSTALL SAP NW JAVA /ADS)
‚Ä¢ LOCAL_HTTP
‚Ä¢ LOCAL_HTTPS
‚Ä¢ S4FIN_HTTPS

SAP Enable Now Web Assistant enter tCode /UI2/FLP_CUS_CONF

Adapt the Fiori notification URL. enter tCode /UI2/FLP_SYS_CONF

Adapt Enterprise Search

Apply product license keys

Install software product license key: Technical restrictions may apply if you don‚Äôt install the license. Use the link to obtain license key.
HANA DB license key can be installed via HANA Studio (Preferences -> License)
In SAP S/4HANA 1909 the license key is installed via SAP logon tCode SLICENSE

Further post-installation checks

Install SAP client tools on your local computers

You can take a full backup and remove the temporary links that were setup for S4H

In client 000 fix transport configuration. Enter tCode SE06 and reinstall CTS transport system, Change originals to S4D, Delete old TMS config, delete old versions of transport routes

Adapt any SAP parameters due to changed SID

The database should be with log mode overwrite and you may like to change that as needed.Please carry out the the other basis steps that are usually done with SID change/System refresh :

SPAD - Spool Administration
SCC4 - Client Administration - Logical System
RZ10- Instance profiles
SP01 - Spool delete old spool requests

PART3: INSTALL SAP NW JAVA / ADS

STEP 1: PREPARE SYSTEM Prepare Linux Server as below for the appliance. The values in Used column below show the minimum size needed. Total filesystem needed is min 70GB for installation.

Plan the change of SID, hostname, instance number. Please refer to the notes below for reserved SIDs SAP Note 1979280 ‚Äì Reserved SAP System Identifiers (SAPSID) with Software Provisioning Manager and hostnames SAP Note 611361 ‚Äì Hostnames of SAP ABAP Platform servers

The table below shows standard SID and hostnames and what we are changing it to.

The /etc/hostname and /etc/host file is below:

STEP 2: EXTRACT FILES

Extract files 51059242_5.ZIP  in /sapmedia

sid-j2d:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_5.ZIP

We will install Java instance from files in  /sapmedia/51059242_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP32ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices

cd /sapmedia/51059242_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP32ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices

In the next step we will extract the above *.tgz files but please note the directories size is as follows so you can provide ample space:

These files will be extracted under /sapmnt/J2E; /usr/sap/J2E and /sybase/J2E. After these are extracted you can rename the filesystem or remount with changed mount points.

sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat dblog.tgz-*  | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat dbexe.tgz-*  | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat dbdata.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat sapmnt_j2e.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat usrsap_j2e.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

STEP 3: GET PASSWORDS Download the file below and open the file in Internet Explorer to note passwords:
/sapmedia/51059242_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP32ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices/SAP_Software_Appliance.xml

STEP 4: RENAME MOUNT POINTS You can take a full OS backup at this point and rename mount points or directories to /sybase/J2D; /sapmnt/J2D; /usr/sap/J2D. The old standard mount points do not have to exist. After reboot ensure all new renamed mount points are valid.

STEP 5 EXTRACT SWPM Extract SWPM in folder /install. Use the SAPCAR already available to extract.

sid-j2d:/install #/sapmnt/J2D/exe/uc/linuxx86_64/SAPCAR -xvf /sapmedia/SWPM10SP45_2-20009701.SAR

STEP 6 RENAME SAP SYSTEM Rename instance using sapinst

sid-j2d:/install # ./sapinst SAPINST_USE_HOSTNAME=vhcalj2dci 

Copy below URL into chrome browser to start sapinst rename process:

https://sid-j2d.dummy.nodomain:4237/sapinst/docs/index.html

In SAPINST select System Rename => Standard System => SAP System Rename

At the screen Software Integrity click on Next

At screen SAP System Parameters enter Source System J2E and Target System J2D:
Click on Next.

At the screen Prerequisite Checker Results accept or fix the Prerequisite check results.
Click on Next. No if you don't want to repeat the test

At the screen SAP Instance Parameters accept or change the Target System Instance Numbers.
Click on Next.

At the screen Database System Type keep the default selection SAP Adaptive Server Enterprise for Business Suite

At the screen Operating System Users accept master password or enter password Xxxxxxxn

At the screen Operating System User for SAP Database Administrator enter the password for sybj2d and User ID and Click on Next

At the screen SAP ASE Database System Parameters accept or change ports and Click on Next

At the screen Database User Passwords enter the passwords for user sa, sapsa, sapsso, SAPSR3DB which is Welcome_2Welcome_2. Click on Next

At the screen DNS Domain Name checkmark Set FQDN for SAP System and enter domain name dummy.nodomain Click on Next

At the screen Media Browser select the media Package Location and Click on Next

At next screen Cleanup of Operating System Users checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next

Here is the Parameter Summary Click on Next to confirm and begin the installation.

After about 10mins, the installation process will stop at this point.

You may get Warning below for rename of profile parameter. Found possible references to the source system in the profile directory of the target system /sapmnt/J2D/profile 

Please take note and proceed.

After the sapinst installation is complete, you can manually start/stop the SAP Java instance J2D using old startsap / stopsap commands

sid-j2d:/install # su - j2dadm
sid-j2d:j2dadm > startsap

To access JAVA server as SAP Netweaver Administrator the URL is:
https://sid-j2d.dummy.nodomain:50000/nwa

Standard users are as follows:
JAVA Administrator ‚Äì Adminitstrator / <Master Password> ;
Java user BPINST/Welcome1

STEP 7: POST STEPS Follow steps from guide attached to SAP Note 2041140 - First Steps for on-premise installations.pdf - Section 5 Technical Post-deployment Activities

Apply product license keys if you haven't installed during swpm install step before. Technical restrictions may apply if you don‚Äôt install the license. Use the link to obtain license key. SAPNetweaver 7.5 J2EE license key has to be installed via SAP Netweaver Administrator

Further post-installation checks
Adapt any SAP parameters due to changed SID
After instance is started and confirmed you can delete the sapmedia folder.

SUPPORT TICKETS:

If you have any difficulty downloading the media open OSS message using component XX-SER-SAPSMP-SWC. If you have issues with technical deployment open message with component BC-INS-SRN.

OTHER REFERENCES:

SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance: Create your SAP S/4HANA system in a fraction of the usual setup time
SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance: Demo Guides

Blogs with known issues (2022 / 2021 / 2020), continuously updated

2041140 - Order an SAP pre-assembled Best Practices software appliance (as partner or customer)

Thank you. Hope you enjoyed the installation.

Mahesh Sardesai
Product Expert ‚Äì S/4HANA
